It serves as both a public park and a research garden for the University of Helsinki. The park is divided into two sections: the southern part features evergreen rhododendrons, while the northern part showcases deciduous azaleas. The blooming season peaks in early June, with azaleas flowering first, sometimes lasting even after Midsummer. The park was established in 1975 with the aim of breeding rhododendrons suitable for the Finnish climate and has wooden walkways for visitors. It's a popular spot, attracting thousands of locals and garden enthusiasts during the flowering season.

name: Viikin pelto
description: Viikin pelto is a valuable combination of bird wetland, field and forest in Viikki, Helsinki. The fields are part of the University of Helsinki's Viikki Research Farm, providing infrastructure for research, teaching, and outreach. The fields are located in the middle of the Viikki recreational area and the university campus. Crops and grass silage for 60 cows are produced in the fields. Part of the fields are used as pasture for cows every year. The fields are an essential part of the birdlife of Vanhankaupunginlahti, serving as feeding and resting areas.

name: Viikki Arboretum
description: Viikki Arboretum is located in Helsinki, it was established in 1969 for dendrological research and teaching purposes. It is part of the Vanhankaupunginlahti outdoor and recreational area. The arboretum covers approximately 20 hectares and features both Finnish and foreign tree and shrub species that thrive in Finland. Foreign species are from areas in the northern hemisphere that closely resemble Finland. Currently, there are around 250 different tree and shrub species growing in the area. It serves as a popular recreational area and a valuable green space within the city.

name: Malminkartano Apple Tree Garden
description: Malminkartano Apple Tree Garden is located in western Helsinki. It's a spacious garden with hundreds of apple trees, as well as some pear, plum, and cherry trees. Originally, it was a research project for the University of Helsinki. Nowadays, it's a public park where people can have picnics and pick apples. The city usually organizes apple picking events in the autumn, and during May, when the trees are in bloom, people come to admire the blossoms. The garden has tables for picnics and open gates for public access. It's a green and peaceful area that offers a chance to enjoy nature and outdoor activities.

name: Meilahti Rosarium
description: Meilahti Rosarium is located in Helsinki, within the Meilahti Arboretum, between Johannesbergintie and Meilahdentie. The rosarium showcases a collection of European historical roses and hardy Finnish shrub roses. The rose varieties are grouped according to their historical or botanical background, and each rose has a name tag. The first rose collection was established in 1991, and it was renovated in 2006-2007, when many varieties were replaced. All the roses are shrub roses, and there are no hybrid tea roses. In addition to the rose bushes, there is also a perennial group and a pergola for climbing roses and clematis. The rose varieties have been selected in collaboration with the Finnish Rose Society. The best time to visit is usually from mid-June to mid-August.

name: Meilahti arboretum
description: Meilahti Arboretum, established in 1967, is located in Helsinki between Johannesbergintie and Meilahdentie streets. This peaceful park covering over three hectares showcases a variety of trees and shrubs, with over 300 species identified with nameplates. A highlight is the rosarium, featuring a collection of shrub roses. The park is designed for educational purposes, inviting visitors to explore and learn about plants within a lush environment. It is managed by the City of Helsinki, with the Finnish Rose Society also contributing to the upkeep of the rose garden.

name: Helsinki Winter Garden
description: Helsinki Winter Garden (Talvipuutarha in Finnish) is a greenhouse located in Helsinki, near Töölönlahti Bay. Established in 1893, it has been a popular place for recreation. The garden is open to the public year-round with no admission fee. It features three distinct rooms: the Palm Room, the Cactus Room, and the West Wing, each offering different botanical experiences with over 200 plant species. During the Christmas and Easter seasons, the garden is decorated with seasonal flowers and decorations. In the summer, the rose garden in front of the Winter Garden is a sight to see.

name: Kaisaniemi Botanic Garden
description: The Kaisaniemi Botanic Garden, established in 1829, is located in the heart of Helsinki. It's one of the two botanical gardens of the University of Helsinki. The garden features diverse collections of living plants both outdoors and in glasshouses. The glasshouses offer a tropical atmosphere, showcasing plants from rainforests and deserts. The outdoor garden is landscaped in an English style, with a formal garden at its center. It includes a systematic garden, a sensory garden, ponds, and flower displays, providing a unique experience for nature enthusiasts all year round.

name: Niskalan arboretum
description: Niskala Arboretum is located in Helsinki, near the Haltiala farm in the northeastern part of the Central Park. Founded in the early 20th century by Jakob Kavaleff, it was initially a show area for his nursery. The arboretum features over 700 plant species from around the world and is divided into different continents. It has a small pond, adventure trails, and benches for picnics. In 1984, the 2.2-hectare original arboretum was declared a nature conservation area. Today, visitors can explore the area using the new signposts and nature trails.

name: Kuusijärvi Outdoor Recreation Area
description: Kuusijärvi Outdoor Recreation Area, located in Vantaa near Helsinki, is a popular year-round destination. In summer, it offers a sandy beach for swimming and sunbathing, along with hiking trails. Winter transforms it into a haven for ice swimming and cross-country skiing. A unique feature is the public smoke saunas, available during the winter season. A pedestrian bridge connects Kuusijärvi to Sipoonkorpi National Park, expanding hiking opportunities. The area also has a cafe, and provides facilities like restrooms, and meeting spaces.

name: Sudentassu
description: Sudentassu, also known as Sipoonkorpi bridge, is located in Vantaa and it connects the outdoor recreation area of Kuusijärvi and Sipoonkorpi National Park. The name "Sudentassu" translates to "wolf's paw" in English. This pedestrian and cycling bridge stretches 126 meters in length and stands 20 meters high, offering an easy way to cross from one rocky cliff to another. It was opened in December 2019. The bridge's architecture is inspired by the surrounding nature and the railings are decorated with animal and plant motifs of the area. In 2021, Sudentassu was awarded the Bridge of the Year prize in Finland.

name: Bisajärvi Cooking Shelter
description: The Bisajärvi Cooking Shelter, or "Bisajärven keittokatos" in Finnish, is located in Sipoonkorpi National Park, near Helsinki. It's a simple open-sided structure with a roof, designed to provide a space for cooking outdoors. Inside, there is usually a fire pit or grill, often with a chimney to direct smoke away. The cooking shelter provides a roof over your head but is open on the sides. These shelters typically accompany picnic tables and a woodshed. It is about 3 kilometers away from Kuusijärvi. These cooking shelters offer a practical and safe environment for visitors to prepare food and enjoy a meal in nature. Camping is allowed near the campfire sites at Bisajärvi.

name: Högberget
description:
Högberget is a notable location in the Helsinki metropolitan area. There are multiple places called Högberget. In Vantaa, Högberget is a 74-meter-high hill within the Sipoonkorpi forest. Its prominent cliff face rises 50 meters above the surrounding Sotunki farmland. The summit features smooth rock formations shaped during the Ice Age. Högberget became part of Sipoonkorpi National Park in 2011.

In Kirkkonummi, close to Helsinki, Högberget's Cave is a unique erosion cave formed during the Ice Age. Meltwater carved a vertical, onion-shaped hole in the rock. It's also known as the "Womb of Mother Earth" because the cave's entrance resembles a vagina. The cave is about 6.5 meters long, 2 meters tall, and 1 meter wide.

name: Kalkkiruukki Lean-to Shelter
description: Kalkkiruukki Lean-to Shelter is located in Vantaa, within the Sipoonkorpi National Park. It's situated along the Kalkinpolttajanpolku trail and is easily accessible from Kalkkiuunintie road. The area has historical significance, formerly belonging to the Håkansböle Manor, where limestone was mined and burned. The lean-to provides a resting spot for hikers. It includes a campfire site, a dry toilet, table-bench sets and a sleeping shelter. Camping is allowed nearby. The Kalkinpolttajanpolku Trail, leading to the shelter, is a 4.8 km circular route known for its varied terrain, including forests and rocky cliffs. It's a popular spot, especially on weekends.

name: Bakunkärr Cooking Shelter
description: The Bakunkärr Cooking Shelter is located in Sipoonkorpi National Park, about 20 kilometers from Helsinki. It's situated on a cliff near Lake Bakunkärrträsket, along the Knuters Trail. The shelter is spacious, featuring a fireplace and seating for a large group. Next to the shelter, on top of the cliff, are tables and benches. A firewood shed and a dry toilet with toilet paper are also available. The Bakunkärr Trail, a 2-kilometer loop, leads to the cooking shelter, with the path to the shelter marked by orange diamonds. Tenting is permitted at the Bakunkärr fireplace, within designated camping areas.

name: Pirttimäki Outdoor Recreation Area
description:
Pirttimäki Outdoor Recreation Area, owned by the city of Helsinki, is a 430-hectare area located in Espoo. It's a popular destination for outdoor activities year-round. The area features diverse terrain shaped by the Ice Age, including steep cliffs, boulders, lakes, ponds, and wetlands.

Pirttimäki is a great starting point for hiking and skiing, with 20 km of marked trails. The trails are also suitable for mountain biking. In winter, cross-country skiing tracks are maintained. The area also includes Pirttimäki lodge with a café and rental saunas. Additionally, there's a 1.8-hectare hazel grove which is a unique sight.

name: Meerlampi Cave
description: Meerlampi Cave, also known as Meerlammen luola in Finnish, is located in Espoo, near Helsinki. It's a natural rock shelter featuring massive boulders, inviting exploration. Situated close to the Haltia Nature Centre and Nuuksio National Park, it's easily accessible for tourists and locals alike. The cave provides a unique opportunity to admire Finland's natural landscape and geological formations. The surrounding area offers peaceful spots near the water, ideal for picnics and photography, making it a perfect destination for family outings or solo adventures in nature. It's open year-round, showcasing the beauty of every season.

name: Maahisenkierros Observation Deck
description: The Maahisenkierros Observation Deck is located in Nuuksio, near the Finnish Nature Center Haltia. The 2 km trail leading to the deck is mostly accessible, even with a wheelchair and prams with assistance, and offers beautiful views. The path goes through the forest and rocky pine forest. The highlight is the observation deck with a magnificent view over Lake Pitkäjärvi. The wide path has a hard surface, and there are resting spots along the route where you can sit and enjoy the scenery.

name: Kattilajärvi Beach
description: Kattilajärvi Beach is located in Espoo, in the Nuuksio lake district, surrounded by a nature reserve. It's known as one of the most peaceful and secluded beaches in the Helsinki Metropolitan Area. The beach itself is small but clean. The area is quiet, almost silent, and the Kattilaniemi camping site is nearby. Getting there is easiest by car, as it's a few kilometers from Nuuksiontie. There's also a campfire site, cooking shelter and well. You can swim from the sandy beach or from the pier. The water is clear and the landscape is beautiful.

name: Holma-Saarijärvi campsite
description: Holma-Saarijärvi campsite is located in the heart of Nuuksio National Park, near Helsinki. It offers beautiful scenery and peaceful nature. There are two camping areas open to everyone. One is on an island on the southern shore of Holma-Saarijärvi. This campsite is a central spot in Nuuksio National Park and is often busy. Facilities include a campfire site, a lean-to shelter next to the bridge to the island, and an outhouse. The other camping area is on the western shore of the lake, also equipped with a campfire site and an outhouse. Holma-Saarijärvi is a great hiking and swimming location.

name: Rajakallio
description: Rajakallio appears in several contexts in the Helsinki metropolitan area. One is a climbing area in Lahti, about an hour's drive from Helsinki, known for winter climbing. Another Rajakallio is a cliff area located in Haukilahti, Espoo, near the Gulf of Finland. Haukilahti is a quiet neighborhood with forests and parks. Karoliina Rajakallio is also mentioned as Unit Director, Enterprise Resource Planning at Kaupunkiliikenne Oy, the Helsinki city transport company. Finally, Rajakallio is mentioned near Nuuksio park as a place to find hotels nearby.

name: Haukkalampi Scenic Spot
description: Haukkalampi is located in the eastern part of Nuuksio National Park, Espoo. It is a popular recreational area with a pond, the Natura Viva rental place, and Café Haukka. Several marked trails begin from Haukkalampi Nature Information Hut, including a 2 km nature trail and the 8 km Korpinkierros trail. The 4 km Haukankierros trail is a popular day trip that circles Haukkalampi. You can also find campfire sites, camping areas, and cooking shelters with firewood. A connecting trail leads to the Finnish Nature Center Haltia. The Hawk's Nest sauna is a popular place to relax after hiking.

name: Poseidon Temple
description:
It seems there might be multiple places named "Poseidonin Temppeli" (Temple of Poseidon) in Finland.

One is located on Iso Vasikkasaari island in Espoo, near Helsinki. It is not actually a temple, but a private building built in the late 19th century as a villa in the style of a Greek temple. A municipal counselor built it for his son-in-law, a professor of the Greek language. Today, the "temple" is used as a fishing lodge and was once the workspace of the sociologist Erik Allardt.

Another "Poseidonin Temppeli" is a bus/metro station in Helsinki.

There is also the actual Temple of Poseidon, located in Sounion, near Athens, Greece. It was built in 444–440 BC, featuring 42 white marble columns, and housed a six-meter bronze statue of Poseidon.

name: Lukukallio rock
description: Lukukallio is a rocky, forested area located in Espoo, near Helsinki, specifically east of Kehä II (Ring Road II) and opposite Suurpelto. It's being planned for housing and commercial development, with considerations to preserve its natural features and ecological connections. The area is known for being a relatively quiet area due to the elevation of the rock which helps to block out noise. It also serves as a habitat for species such as the Siberian flying squirrel.

name: Lookout Point
description: Helsinki offers many scenic viewpoints. One popular spot is Malminkartanonhuippu, the highest point in Helsinki, created from landfill. Climbing its 426 steps rewards you with panoramic city views. Another option is the tower of the Helsinki Olympic Stadium, standing at 72 meters, it provides a historical perspective of the city. For a different experience, visit Ateljee Bar on top of Hotel Torni, offering stunning views of the coastline and city center from a rooftop terrace. Kaivopuisto Park also provides scenic ocean cliffs overlooking the southern coast and archipelago.

name: Salapaikka
description: "Salapaikka" translates to "secret place" or "hideout" in Finnish. It can refer to a favorite, personal spot where one can relax and contemplate. However, "Salapaikka" is also the name of a shop, Salakauppa (Secret Shop), located in Helsinki. Salakauppa is a shop run by COMPANY (Aamu Song & Johan Olin) that sells unique items and has a history of art installations and special events. The shop's interior has a mural painting filled with workshops, factories and travel stories. The shop also has a small studio in the back where they make more products.

name: World War I Fortresses
description: During World War I (1914-1918), a fortification zone was built around Helsinki as part of Russia's defense of St. Petersburg. This included three lines of land fortifications in Helsinki, Vantaa, and Espoo, and coastal artillery. Known as Krepost Sveaborg, it extended around Helsinki with structures like trenches and concrete shelters. The fortifications, built by Finnish workers and even Chinese laborers, were largely unused. Today, over 300 structures remain, some preserved while others have been destroyed, offering a glimpse into WWI-era military engineering in the Helsinki region. Some locations like Mustavuori have well-preserved trenches and caves.

name: Taivarin mäki
description: Taivarinmäki, also known as Taivari, was a ski jumping hill located in Laajalahti, Espoo. The landing slope of the hill was removed and became unusable due to the construction of the Tarvontie road. It is mentioned among other old place names in the Espoo area.

name: Stockmann Ruins
description: The Stockmann Ruins are located in Kauniainen, near Helsinki. These aren't actually ruins but the foundation of an unfinished mansion. Frans Stockmann, from the famous Stockmann department store family, started building the grandiose villa in the early 1900s, but construction was halted when he and his wife died of the Spanish flu in 1919 and 1920, respectively. Today, the stone foundation sits in the forest, with nature slowly reclaiming it. Visitors can explore the site, where they can also find graffiti art. The ruins offer a glimpse into what might have been a magnificent home and a reminder of a tragic period in history.

name: Matalajärvi Birdwatching Tower
description: Matalajärvi birdwatching tower is located in Espoo, next to the Matalajärvi lake. The lake is part of the Natura 2000 network and Nuuksio National Park and is a nationally significant bird wetland. From the bird tower, you can spot various bird species like the Whooper Swan, the Coot, and the Common Snipe. The lake is shallow, with a maximum depth of just over a meter, making it an important resting area for migrating birds. The tower provides a good view of almost the entire lake area. It is recommended to bring a telescope but binoculars are also sufficient to spot birds. The closest parking area is at Pehtorinaukio from where you can walk to the lake.

name: Hilan louhos
description: Hilan louhos is a former quarry located in Kirkkonummi, near Helsinki. Mining operations started in 1986 and ceased almost 20 years ago after an expansion permit was rejected. A lake with depths of up to 11 meters has formed in the quarry. The steep quarry walls, reaching nearly 10 meters high, and inadequate safety fences create a dangerous environment. Despite this, the quarry has become a popular, though hazardous, swimming and diving spot, attracting both families and young people. There have been issues with disturbances and parking problems in the area.

name: Torhola Cave
description: Torhola Cave is Finland's largest limestone cave, located in Lohja, not near Helsinki. To reach it, you can take a 1.5-hour bus ride from Helsinki to Karkali and then walk about 500 meters. The cave is around 30 meters long with narrow passages and cavities to explore, reaching depths of up to 12 meters. It was mainly formed by melting water after the last Ice Age. The surrounding area has elm and lime forests with various plant and fungus species. Inside the cave, there are often ice formations in winter. Non-slip shoes and a flashlight are recommended.
